com.tinkerpop.pipes

Class AbstractPipe<S,E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tinkerpop.pipes.AbstractPipe<S,E>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Pipe<S,E>, Iterable<E>, Iterator<E>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractMetaPipe, AggregatePipe, CollectionFilterPipe, CountPipe, CyclicPathFilterPipe, DuplicateFilterPipe, EdgesVerticesPipe, ExpandablePipe, FilterFunctionPipe, FunctionPipe, GatherFunctionPipe, GatherPipe, GroupByPipe, GroupCountFunctionPipe, GroupCountPipe, HasCountPipe, IdEdgePipe, IdentityPipe, IdFilterPipe, IdPipe, IdVertexPipe, IfThenElsePipe, IntervalFilterPipe, LabelFilterPipe, LabelPipe, LinkPipe, ObjectFilterPipe, OrderMapPipe, OrderPipe, PathPipe, PropertyFilterPipe, PropertyMapPipe, PropertyPipe, QueryPipe, RandomFilterPipe, RangeFilterPipe, ScatterPipe, SelectPipe, ShufflePipe, SideEffectFunctionPipe, StorePipe, TablePipe, ToStringPipe, TransformFunctionPipe, TreePipe, VerticesEdgesPipe, VerticesVerticesPipe

    public abstract class AbstractPipe<S,E>
extends Object
implements Pipe<S,E>
    An AbstractPipe provides most of the functionality that is repeated in every instance of a Pipe. Any subclass of AbstractPipe should simply implement processNextStart(). The standard model is 
     protected E processNextStart() throws NoSuchElementException {
   S s = this.starts.next();
   E e = // do something with the S to yield an E
   return e;
 }
    If the current incoming S is not to be emitted and there are no other S objects to process and emit, then throw a NoSuchElementException.
    Author:
    Marko A. Rodriguez (http://markorodriguez.com)

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Description copied from interface: Pipe
        A pipe may maintain state. Reset is used to remove state. The general use case for reset() is to reuse a pipe in another computation without having to create a new Pipe object. An implementation of this method should be recursive whereby the starts (if a Pipe) should have this method called on it.
        Specified by:
        reset in interface Pipe<S,E>

      • enablePath

        public void enablePath(boolean enable)
        Description copied from interface: Pipe
        Calculating paths can be an expensive operation for some pipes. This method is used to activate or deactivate the calculation of paths. The default state of a newly constructed pipe should have its path calculations disabled. An implementation of this method should be recursive whereby the starts (if a Pipe) should have this method called on it.
        Specified by:
        enablePath in interface Pipe<S,E>
        Parameters:
        enable - enable path calculations

      • iterator

        public Iterator<E> iterator()
        The iterator method of Iterable is not faithful to the Java semantics of iterator(). This method simply returns the pipe itself (which is an iterator) and thus, is useful only for foreach iteration.
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Iterable<E>
        Returns:
        the pipe from the perspective of an iterator
